description.text:
This is a minor remix of a superb original vase design, sliced for the MakerBot Replicator Z18.  
It is re-sized to fill the build area, using a custom profile, with no roof, no infill and walls 2 shells thick.  
It's a good workout for the Z18, standing at 45cm tall  
It takes 24 hours to print.  
It's not necessarily watertight in the literal sense - put water in at your own risk!

Toys for dogs

Here is a game designed to challenge young children just learning how to count and recognize colors. Each disc is designed to fit perfectly in its corresponding peg. For example, the number 1 disc will not fit on the number 5 peg.
This design was inspired by a similar wooden version that my little brother had when he was a young boy.

comments.author: alwhit

comments.text:
Hi,
I wrote some Python to convert the raw NASA SRTM data into STL (3D triangles). The SRTM data is formatted as Latitude, Longitude, Altitude so you need to convert to OSGB coordinates (N, E, Altitude) first to get rid of the curvature. The Lat / Lon resolution for the UK is 3 arcseconds which corresponds to roughly 90m on the ground. So if you want to print small areas you need to be careful that you don't zoom in too far or the data will quickly start to look pixelated.
Code is now available on GitHub: https://github.com/PaulZC/SRTM_to_STL
Enjoy! (Usual conditions apply! WYSIWYG...)
Cheers,
Paul

A simple Landing Gear for quadcopter.

Based on thing:337267, with following changes:
  • Split into upper and lower part to simplify print and assembly.
  • Upper part has been reinforced
  • Lower part now is inserted into hot-end instead of being attached to extruder tension arm.
    • Have some hours of printing with Ninjaflex during December 2014, working OK.
    Does not obstruct when printing PLA. Actually makes it a little bit easier to thread new filament. NB: work-in-progress
  • You may need to extend the holes in upper part a little bit to avoid upper filament support conflicting with hobbled knob

Printed at 100% fill. Recommented is to print ninjaflex-support-lower-tube for the lower part. It is simpler and more reliable than previous design. It can be tricky to print right because being so small, you may need to try a couple of prints to get it right.
In Cura on my machine I needed to scale to 1.05 for it to create the toolpaths, and use fill = 50% to get the right dimensions.

comments.text: Best solution ive used yet. I took a drill bit to the core to widen it and filed down the outer layer with a dremel to get it to fit. Printed with black pla at low temperature (190) with fan on after first 2 layers to solidify quickly and prevent bending when printing the cylinder. Printing ninjaflex at 10mm/s and 235 degrees. Looking good so far. For the upper portion i used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:422289. Works well together on printrbot simple metal 2015

Well, my tinkering and modifying is done, this is the final version... Behold, the mighty balloon powered LOLCOPTER Mk1! NOW FULLY CUSTOMIZABLE!!
AND IMPROVED - See Instructions :) Which means endless possibilities! It's got turbines, it's got propellers, everything is customizable, play with the settings and see how high can you make it fly. Make it how you want it to be, blow up a balloon, put it on and let it soar :) I'd love to see how many different designs come out of this and which ones fly best. This is my very first OpenSCAD model, I haven't done any coding before this, and boy, what a learning curve, but I'm proud to say that I've written every line of code in this script! It's amazing what variables and a single line of code can do! I wanted to make something fun to learn how to use openSCAD and the Makerbot Customizer app. Inspiration and coding lessons came from many sources, but credit for inspiration also goes to these two makers; http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:47565
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26269 OpenSCAD is a lot of fun; I think I'm addicted!
I can't wait to get into my next project! I encourage and welcome all feedback on any aspect of this design, especially on how easy or hard the parts are to print. I'm happy to make changes to make it better. EDIT: Big propellers are working
EDIT EDIT: Baloon stem made betterer :)
EDIT EDIT EDIT: now with Thingiviews
EDIT EDIT EDIT EDIT: improvements- see instructions

Make your own STLs from the customizer, the samples aren't located correctly, bu the script fixes that. I've designed this to be fully assembled needing no extra parts other than what is provided in the list for printing, other than a good balloon of course :)
  • You can change just about everything on this LOLCOPTER - I've designed it so you can customize it to optimize the design to give the best performance and to suit your printing envelope.
    • NOTE:
    CHANGE THE DIMENSIONS WITH CUSTOMIZER RATHER THAN SCALING THE STLs TO SUIT YOUR PRINTER, THAT'S WHAT CUSTOMIZER IS FOR :) EDIT EDIT: turbine airflow has been largely improved
    EDIT: I've made the STLs export the correct way up for printing and they should be in the center of your envelope.
    I've also tightened up some clearances to make the airflow better.
    The text is now in relief instead of being embossed.
    ALSO- See images for the right way to install the turbines and propellers. So...
  • Select your desired font and write some text on the front and or top, or leave blank if you prefer none.
    Then change;
  • Distance between the props
  • The number of blades on the propellers
  • The size of the turbines
  • The height of the propellers
  • The thickness of the propeller shafts
  • Even the balloon stem size
    • NOTES :

  • no matter what sizes you customize on this LOLCOPTER, I have ensured that the wall
    thickness always remains a constant 2mm thick.

  • When assembling the turbines, make sure you put them in the right way up and the right way around; the blades should be curving towards the middle of the copter, the big hole should be on the bottom.
  • The propellers should be assembed so that the blades curve up and away from the center of the copter.
    (Looking down on top of the copter with the words facing you, the propeller on the right should be spinning anti-clockwise, and the one on the left should be spinning the opposite, to give lift.
    • Customize away, assemble and put on an inflated balloon, the bigger the better, and watch LOLCOPTER take to the sky, flying with all the glory of the internet. Exporting:
    Clicking on the 'Create STL' button in the Customizer App creates an STL for all the nominated parts in the script, the drop down menu is only for a visual on-screen preview of each part.

author: alejandro183

description.text:
2-part case for 12V -> 24V DC boost circuit (ebay 271416568548 "DC-DC 12V to 19V24V15V Adjustable Boost Converter Power Module Battery Charge"). I'm using this to take 12V battery power and drive 24V into a PoE remote camera setup (too much cable loss to work directly at 12V) but I needed a case for the bare PCB assy as it comes from ebay. Tested at 24V @ 1 A output, where it is 88% efficient and doesn't get even slightly warm. There is one slight mod needed to the top half of the case: the green terminal block has a small ridge at one side I didn't model, which interferes with the plastic sidewall. It is a tight fit even without the ridge. I fixed that quickly with some sidecutters. Maybe I'll add that notch to the case for v2 if I get around to it. This design includes a cutout under the terminal block for the input and output wires I soldered there (more reliable than screw connections). There is a small hole directly over the trim pot for a thin screwdriver for output voltage adjustment.
Assembles with 4x M3 x 25mm screws, mine are Pololu #1077 and the threaded part measures 24.8 mm. Any length over 25.0 mm will not work properly. There are no nuts; this design relies on the M3 screws biting into the 3 mm length of plastic boss on the bottom part of the case. Not too strong but seems to work (at least with my particular printer, UM2).

title: Dr.RobotLabs Adafruit Analog Camera Case, Lego Optical Cage System for 1/2 Diameter Lenses and Small TV Case

description.text:
While reprapping, I have made many microscope techniques, my best solution thus far is to work with analog cameras rather then webcams. So I like Adafruits Analog Camera - http://www.adafruit.com/products/397. There is also a case for Adafruits TV
https://www.adafruit.com/products/910 But its pretty lame needs some improvement except you can mount on aluminum extrusion (30mm) and its easy to fix to 20mm. So I wanted to make an optical cage system for this using custom focal length lens 1/2" diameter. The cage system can interface filters or even beam splitters ... potentially it should be straightforward to do now with it anyway. The holes fit the lego black square rods and you have an option to put in a M4 lead screw for zooming. That is about as far as I went with this. I just use this for making different working distance lenses. I want to make mounts for Dr.Robotlabs Repstrap Library.

Here is the list of functions. I also upload a driver file you had edit the module and see the imagines through the driver file. I also put the Adafruit tv monitor that I used as a separate set of functions. Sorry lazy Here is the list for the optical cage system ..
12ptStar(size, height) - OpenSCAD Shapes Library (www.openscad.org) Copyright (C) 2009 Catarina Mota
adjustcaselid() - This is the lid that covers the camera case, it can be modified to fit a bandpass filter. Its set up to accomidate a threaded rod if for zooming used with M4 threaded rod and 2 lego guides
adjustcaselid_nothread() - This is the lid that covers the camera case, it can be modified to fit a bandpass filter.
baseassembly() - Adafruit analog camera base assembly used with M4 threaded rod and 2 lego guides (black rods)
baseassembly_nothread() - Adafruit analog camera base assembly
box(size) - OpenSCAD Shapes Library (www.openscad.org) Copyright (C) 2009 Catarina Mota
cammount() - This supports underside of this Adafruit analog camera so its nice and close to the lid orifice
case() - The actual case part that fits the camera and cammount
caselid() - Its also a case lid but doesn't hold an M4 nut like adjustcaselid() <- which is supposed to move.
caselid_nothread() - no thread so its similar probably to adjustcaselid_nothread()
cone(height, radius, center = false) - OpenSCAD Shapes Library (www.openscad.org) Copyright (C) 2009 Catarina Mota
dislocateBox(w,h,d) - OpenSCAD Shapes Library (www.openscad.org) Copyright (C) 2009 Catarina Mota
dodecagon(size, height) - OpenSCAD Shapes Library (www.openscad.org) Copyright (C) 2009 Catarina Mota
equiTriangle(side, height) - OpenSCAD Shapes Library (www.openscad.org) Copyright (C) 2009 Catarina Mota
hexagon(size, height) - OpenSCAD Shapes Library (www.openscad.org) Copyright (C) 2009 Catarina Mota
hexagram(size, height) - OpenSCAD Shapes Library (www.openscad.org) Copyright (C) 2009 Catarina Mota
inner() - Designed to hold Thorlabs 1/2" diameter biconvex lenses and simlar in place
2 Plano-convex lens 20mm focal length
(LA1074 1/2" 20.0 10.3 4.0 1.8 17.4)
http://www.thorlabs.com/newgrouppage9.cfm?objectgroup_id=112
These 2 lens resting against each other with the convex end facing each other
innerlensguide() - Also designed to hold Thorlabs 1/2" diameter biconvex lenses and simlar in place
lenscap() - Designed to hold Thorlabs biconvex 1/2" diameter lenses and simlar in place

For your annoying wire management needs. This will help keep the spiral cable wrapped wires away from your prints. If you have a fan shroud you will run into issue where the screws will be to short. 3njoy

Very simple print, Just print at your settings and you should be all set. To secure the cable to the holder two zip ties can be threaded through the holes and secured.  
If you have a older model simple metal where the fan bracket does not cover the whole fan you have two options, 1. you can use the MK4 model and the MK4 spacer. The spacer rests against the fan and the bracket rest on top, then secure with all four fan screws, 2. there is a MK4 model with the spacer built on, just one piece.  
If you use the MK4 feedback would be nice so i can adjust it if needed. I have the newer model so I cant test the fitting myself. Thanks

It is a salt/pepper shader formed as a sheep. It is hollowed to be filled with salt or pepper, which can be poured of the nose.

title: Ventilated K8200 Board Cover with mounting lugs

description.text:
The original control board cover for the Velleman K8200 is not very well ventilated. I wanted to improved air flow and remade the front to sport a lot of hex formed holes.
I also wanted the possibility to mount equipment under the cover so I added two mounting lugs. M3 Allen bolts will be a perfect fit.
As the picture shows I have mounted a Raspberry Pi B+ below the cover. The design is a remix of the tightest Pi shell I have found. You can find my remixed version here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:524573

author: Dvogonen

description.text:
A filament wiper helps keep dust and other debris from entering the feeder, bowden, and extruder assembly.  This one is designed to be able to be installed and removed without re-feeding the filament -- you don't need to remember to slide it onto the filament before feeding.  
For use with a lazy-susan turntable, which makes the filament unspool more smoothly.  
Designed for an Ultimaker2, but should work for other printers which use a bottom-feed external feeder.

After printing the wiper, cut two pieces of foam rubber, each about 25x25mm square, 12mm thick when compressed.  (This doesn't have to be precise -- I cut mine from scrap shipping material.) Sandwich the foam squares into the wiper box such that the parting line is facing the open side of the box, aligned with the slits in the box, and parallel to the long axis of the wiper.  (Note to self: add a photo of this.)  
When changing filament, you just need to slide the filament in between the two pieces of foam.  If you align the foam the way I (try to) describe above, you can do this without removing the foam, and without re-feeding the filament.

a big buggy guy
needs some work

Wanted to share this door opener with everyone. It works so well and should have many applications for about anything with small moving doors. This uses a regular size MG996 180 degree servo, controlled by Arduino board or RC transmitter-receiver. This design opens in a wide arc from little movement of servo and has great leverage for the beginning of the lift. Pulls the door shut and holds it. I have the servo working from 13 degrees shut to 150 degrees fully open, so there is a lot more room for bigger doors or longer arms. This is really quite powerful, I have a delay built in to the software to make it look more to scale, but the servo slams the door pretty fast without it. In this application the gear case puts the arm in the middle of the servo, but sure will work just as well with RC airplane type push rods right on servo. My first design with linear pushed at the door instead of up on the door like this does.
Here is a link to a YouTube Video showing it working https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vqUzjV5_Pv4
This was very interesting working with the length of the servo arm. One side needed less throw than the other. Never would have guessed that one. But it works. I notice they do not close the same but reach the ends at the same time. Very interesting. Was able to fine tune the doors by the length of the bone arm from servo arm. If you need some assorted length Bone arms let me know.
Added PDF with pretty accurate anchor placement measurements.
This stuff goes with the Tank Track 2in, Tank Idler arms, pins and other tank parts in my things.
11-26-2014 Just added some heavy duty gears for the gear case. The old ones didn't print very well and teeth didn't hold up. The new HD gears have fewer teeth but they are bigger and will print solid.

Added a PDF layout sheet that I hope will help you. Going to have to play with it to adapt it to whatever, but that is the hole idea.
The gear case screws into whatever the servo is mounted on. Drill to .120" and use #4x3/4" screws. Case will need raft and support. Gear case cover, no raft, screws to case with gears inside, 4x3/8" screws.
The servo gear will print on table. Drill a little smaller than your servo shaft and push on making groves. A 3mm machine screw hold the gear to MG996 servo. I found it really handy to be able to turn the gear on servo to time the gear with the arms. The MG996 servo output shaft diameter is .220" so a little less.
The output gear needs raft and support. Drill out the case and file down to fit so it turns freely with case cover screwed on. A dremel tool that flat cuts on the end was very handy to go around next to gears. Drill out the hex for arm at .093", 4x3/8" screw.
The supports for the arm will need raft and support. Made some universal supports you can use on doors and one end of arm. The ones for the tank will be different.
Arms will need support on the long ones. All of the arms can be attached using a 4x1/4" screw and flat washer with .180 center diameter. Drill holes for screws to .093". Run a small file around the stubs and drill arms to fit. The stubs on arms and supports are .250" but never print perfect that small. Drill the arm eyes in increments to fit. Start with a "D" or "E"/1/4" (.250") bit. Most of them fit nicely with and "F" (.257") or "G" (.261") bits.
The more time you spend fitting everything together nice and tight but moving freely the better the mechanism will operate (don't look at my sloppy fit).
The servo arm for tank needed the arm connecting to the left side of tank with less throw than right. The longer the main supported arm and short connector to the door arm the wider the door will open. Have fun!

comments.text:
I am using an Arduino Micro board with 40 pin zip socket soldered to a 276-150 Radio Shack circuit board. Has 7805 voltage regulator to run servos off battery, 555 timer for flashing LED lights and headlight switch on the RS board. The RS board is all set up to use Futaba JR servo plugs that attach directly to the Arduino Micro through the board. I use the Arduino Micro to control the switches and servo motor to open the shuttle bay doors and will have room to expand whatever I need in the future. Pictures of the board are in the electronics cases for the tank in my things.
To control the motion of the tank I have a Sabertooth 2X12 running the Mabuchi motors through a regular 4 channel Futaba transmitter and receiver. Sabertooth cases and receiver case for the tank are in the Tank electronics cases also.
Links to YouTube videos of the tank running are in the Tank Track, 2in listing in my things.

Just as I had my Prusa nicely dialed in, the Y-axis bearing guide disintegrated on me.  I printed out stock replacements, but really didn't want to disassemble the whole frame to install them.  This is based on the original SCAD files but allows installation in place with nothing more than removing the cog on the stepper to untension the belt.  I can't see any Y-axis skips in the output, so I'm calling it good enough!  
I printed it in HIPS, so I was able to glue it together with toluene-based model cement.  I suppose one could do the same with ABS and acetone, but I wouldn't use cyanoacrylate near a bearing... .

This is a gift box of sorts, made of six identical parts that go together in a somewhat puzzling manner. There are three styles, each held together by a combination of tabs and/or slots. Boxy #1 - Each part has two projecting tabs and two slots; the box is held together by arranging the parts so two tabs on each side lock into the slots of two adjacent sides while two other slides lock into this side's slots. This version works requires material with a balance of flexibility and rigidity. Boxy #2 - Each part has to projecting tabs like #1 plus tabs that lock together in groups of three at the corners. This version works best with fairly flexible material. It's the most secure version, but also the most complicated. Boxy #3 - Each part has tabs that can lock pieces together at the corners. This version works best with fairly rigid material, but needs sufficient flex to get the corners into place without breaking. This is probably the simplest box to assemble. (Undoubtedly it could be adapted to laser cutting, but I haven't translated them.) More pictures and description in my blog at http://mysd300.blogspot.com/2010/12/puzzle-box-gift-cube.html

Build six copies of your choice of models: boxy1.stl, boxy2.stl, or boxy3.stl. Use your sleuthing skills to assemble the six pieces into a cube. For an added challenge, try assembling it with something inside! Default model size is 16cm x 16cm x 1.2mm but it can be scaled at will, provided the material is sufficiently strong (or flexible). If you have a Solido SD300 or 3D Systems Invision LD you can use the files Boxies1.stl, boxies2.stl, or boxies3.stl to build a stack of six parts at the same time. These files have six copies of the model stacked with a 0.175mm gap between them, which will build as a single stack with a layer of unused support material between them.

These finger skis are simple and a good way to entertain yourself while bored at the office, or want something fun to do. They slide onto your fingers easily, and if you have the right size they should slide off easily as well. The ski sizes refer to the opening for your finger, all the files are the same length. The small sized ski has a finger opening 18mm wide, medium has an opening 19mm wide, and the large has an opening 21mm wide. This file has been moved to my mini factory http://www.myminifactory.com/object/finger-skis-3547

I printed with support although I don,t think you need to , as the supports never touched the actual skis, and I designed the finger ring to be printable without support and the ski tips print surprisingly well without support.

title: remix of Boots Industries filament spool holder

description.text:
This is a modification of the Boots Industries (BI) filament spool holder design, published on Thingiverse. As with the original, it uses a single 608ZZ bearing, but uses a bit more 4mm hardware, in order to both clamp the bearing in place securely and to allow fine-tuning of the drag desired to govern spool rotation.
Various brands of filament have spools with different diameters of the hub hole. The BI design requires a different removable adapter piece for each different diameter, where this redesign can support multiple different diameters in a single fixed spinner. With similar slicing paramenters and PLA, the BI base and platform together weigh about 34g, and the redesigned base and multi-diameter spinner together also weigh about 34g. The BI design also needs one adapter per different spool hub hole diameter, at about 27g each. The BI base is 120mm in diameter; the redesigned base files are uploaded at 120mm diameter and 98mm diameter, and other sizes could be readily created by modifying a parameter and recompiling in openSCAD. The spinner design uploaded is for these reel hub hole diameters: 2", 1.5", 1.25", 0.75". Other combinations could be generated by modifying the program parameters in openSCAD and recompiling the spinner.

Important: the openSCAD and STL files provided are in nominal sizes, and need the slicer (MakerWare or other) to have a scaling factor entered to correct for printer calibration and filament shrinkage. The photographed spool holders were printed on MakerBot Replicator (dual) and Replicator 2 printers at TechShop Mid-Peninsula (San Carlos) and TechShop San Jose, using PLA and ABS; a scaling factor of 100.54% was used with good results.
To determine the scaling factor you need, and whether the post for the bore of the bearing is a good fit, you can print the test piece (which is just the center post from the base) and vary the scaling and/or openSCAD parameters as needed to get the test piece diameter at 22mm. The bearing bore should be a light (hand) press fit, and the screw should be threaded into the central shaft. The outside of the bearing should also be a light (hand) press fit into the spinner. No test part is provided for the spinner, as it would not be that much faster to print than a real spinner part. Although a 30mm long screw fits the design best, a 35mm long screw can be more convenient for doing test fits of the bearing, making it easier to remove the spinner if it is a very tight fit on the bearing.
The assembly of all parts is shown in the photograph of a holder with a cut-away spinner. The steps are:
  • thread the screw into the base from the bottom
  • press the bearing bore onto the post
  • tighten a washer and nylon insert locknut onto the bearing
  • press the spinner onto the bearing
  • assemble a washer and nylon insert locknut into the recess at the top of the spinner; do not fully tighten, adjust for desired drag (if any)
    Hardware Required:
    1x 608ZZ bearing
    1x 4mm screw, 30mm long, fully threaded
    1x 4mm screw, 35mm long, fully threaded (optional, for test fitting)
    2x 4mm x 12mm OD flat washer (probably the most challenging part to source)
    2x 4mm nylon insert locknut
    Prices on the 4mm hardware vary considerably: total $.38 from Mr. Metric, but $6.00 shipping if not picked up and order total is less than $50.00. So this would be a good time to stock up on metric hardware, to share or eliminate the shipping cost.
    (#6 hardware could be substituted, washers should still be 12mm OD or .5" OD, and about 4mm ID)
    Tools Required:
    number 2 size Phillips screwdriver
    7mm (probably) nutdriver (or wrench and socket)

title: Lego STLs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A collection of standard Lego bricks, plates, bricks with holes, an axle (not splined) and 2 wheels.
27 files enough for a structure or a vehicle or ... Well, Lego has always wanted you to be creative ....
Build something cool & upload image.
Enjoy !!

Please note: Exported as STL with these settings - Chordal = 0.2 mm
Angular = 7 degrees
Output mode = binary Please advise if unsuitable.

comments.text: I printed a sample of most of these parts but to be honest I don't get it... Some wheels have large holes in the center but none of the parts fit in there to hold an axle. The axles seem too big to fit into anything including the parts that have axle holes. The parts do seem to snap onto standard legos but otherwise I'm a bit lost. Trying to print a ton of legos to contribute to "Toys for Tots" so I was looking for parts that would allow the kids to make vehicles.... Any thoughts?
comments.author: Magikmerlin

comments.text: Anybody print these out yet?  I would love to see some pictures.
comments.author: idolcrasher

comments.text: Thanks for posting - do you have STLs for the standard "+" section axle or any of the technics gears?
comments.author: MarkU

comments.text: I'm looking around. In the meantime, if you have acces to or can convert, Solidworks or ProE then please visit Carnegie Melon for Lego Nxt parts: http://www.education.rec.ri.cmu.edu/content/lego/solid_model/index.htmhttp://www.education.rec.ri.cm...
comments.author: MarkU

comments.text:
As a follow-up - how do you open the files at tracepartsonline? I work with Art Of Illusion
&
amp; Meshlab mostly, but among the long list of options for download format, I can't find one that either of those can work with. Any suggestions?
comments.author: Smoutech

comments.text: They want you to register to add parts to your 'caddy'. Parts are indexed per manufacturer catalogue so you may need to know what you want. Dimensions help you choose something suitable if you don't. Some parts also require you to spend 'credits'. Suppose tracepartsonline is more oriented say towards 'hardcore' engineering than 'artistic' use.
comments.author: MarkU

comments.text: Thanks - I got by the "caddy" thing, it's not so much an issue of downloading in my case, it's just the available download formats are all formats like IGES and ProE etc that I can't find a free-as-in-beer way to open. I have a few files, I just can't actually get into them, and was wondering about your experience working with them - do you own commercial software? Or do you know a good translation path to get them into e.g. STL format?
comments.author: Smoutech

comments.text: Good to know. No access to ProE or Solidworks at this point but maybe in the future. Thanks!
comments.author: Smoutech

author: Smoutech

description.text:
Small lockable container, one I'm using to house my spare change.
Currently has no markings, meaning that if the rings are turned when closed, it could take some time to work open again.

Printed on a Replicator 2 in PLA with standard Medium settings:
10% Infill
2 Shells
0.27 Layer Height The rings are a tight fit and can take a bit of work to turn. I recommend a light sanding before snapping them into place.

KINEO ist ein Roboterprojekt aus Deutschland
Die Servos werden mithilfe eines Arduino Uno angesteuert welcher per I2C mit einem Raspberry Pi (Model A, B oder später B+) kommuniziert.
Ziel ist es eine günstige Roboter platform mit unendlichen möglichkeiten zu entwickeln.
  • Powered by 8 AA Akkus -
    http://youtu.be/wFWkaVhQbp4

    KINEO is a robot project in Germany
    The servos are controlled using an Arduino Uno which via I2C with a Raspberry Pi ( Model A, B or B + later ) communicates .
    The aim is to develop a cheap robot platform with endless possibilities .

    Arduino code coming soon... this month...

Druckeinstellungen 0.3-0.1mm Auflösung
33% Infill
2 Shells
Servo dimensions:
h 24.3 mm x l 23. 8mm x t 11.5 mm
like the G12AM or G12DM Servo
! You must 4 servo motored modify so that the motion direction is correct. Use this manual: youtube.com/watch?v=_bkZcOS32Uc it´s very very easy and makes the robot more beautiful.
Invert the 4 Servos in a front right and rear left starting from the front left clockwise.
For now, this can be used Arduino code, but which is not of me and modify: http://www.engineer-this.com/quadruped.shtml

text = Dr.Shah
A Rapa Nui Moai Easter Island statue with topknot. The topknot has a hole through it, for a key chain.

This was my first successful print after 3 solid days of abort, abort, abort, abort. Found out about clogging nozzles, sticking filament spools, different pull rate for PLA and compatibility of trying to run the latest versions of python, replicatorg and driver (after much head banging, went back two versions to the stable versions, got everything cleaned up and looks like mass replication ahead. I was able to build the statue with raft/no support, although some detail in the feet were lost. The topknot is a separate piece. The base is just the 20mm calibration block. Super glue really holds these parts together.

The input coil for the short wave tube receiver.
Inductance is approximately 5uH and can be changed by the number of windings. If necessary,
If necessary, I will publish a scheme of the receiver (for example: a simple regenerative Audion)
I added a different (spider) coil which is better (read: prettier). Receivers I'll add later when they are made up. The machine, which being in progres is the winder for cross-coils.
Here is a video of still unfinished machine. https://youtu.be/e3_o3FKZH5o https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fZ88H5ARjQY&feature=youtu.be
